comment.author: 52581810@N02
comment._content: Name of the Photographer is Bellingrodt.

comment.author: 89322437@N08
comment._content: Das ist keine Henschel-Wegmann-Lok. Es gab nur 2 Henschel-Wegmann-Züge die aus einer Stromlinien-Tenderlok der Baureihe 61 von Henschel und mehreren Wagen von Wegmann bestanden. Hier sieht man wohl eine 01.10 oder 03.10

comment.author: 52581810@N02
comment._content: This is a 01.10, the three cylinder version of the more common 01 two cylinder engine. At high speeds (120 or even 130 km/h) the two cylinders caused a very shaky ride, so for higer speeds a three cylinder version was designed. In combination with the streamlining they could run up to a speed of 150 km/h. In the late thirties 55 engines were built; more than 200 were ordered, but production was halted at the outbreak of the Second World War in september 1939. All these engines ended up in the western part of Germany, where they ran as 'normal' engines, i.e. without the streamlining, until 1975 with the Deutsche Bundesbahn (Federal Railways). About ten of them still exist in various railway museums in Germany and the Netherlands. One of them got its streamlining back.
